replies.author: BerndBreier

timeline.bodyText: why don't just check modified? It doesn't make sense to me to check the rest as well...
timeline.author: holgerhagen

replies.bodyText: The problem is that the timestamps are not safe to detect concurrent updates. We have already some testcases that fail intermittently due to this problem. With the additional tests (on claimed / state) we simply narrow the failure window. A real solution would be to maintain a version counter on task objects that is updated each time a task is persisted.
replies.author: BerndBreier

timeline.bodyText: Does this handle setPlanned as well. If it does, we probably don't need to initialize it in line 1528.

replies.author: BerndBreier

timeline.bodyText: by the way: should attachment and tasks have the same modification timestamp? It would probably nice, wouldn't it?
timeline.author: holgerhagen

replies.bodyText: I restructured the code so that tasks and attachments that are updated with the task have the same modification timestamp...

replies.bodyText:
This test has no side effects because I added a @beforeeach method that resets the database before each testcase.
However, this could have impact on performance of our build process. Therefore, I think I should remove the @beforeeach method and move this specific testcase into a class of its own.
replies.author: BerndBreier

timeline.bodyText: Do we need the distinction between creation and update? Or could we at least use the same insertion method?
timeline.author: holgerhagen

replies.bodyText:
The difference is:

on task creation, all attachments are inserted. The insertNewAttachmentsOnTaskCreation method just iterates over all attachments and inserts each of them
on task update, only new attachments are inserted. Therefore, method insertNewAttachmentsOnTaskUpdate first detects which attachment is new and then inserts only these attachments.
I think, I will extract the common parts of these two methods into a method insertAttachment. This method would have to initialize the attachment, validate its ObjectReference and then call the mapper to insert it...
replies.author: BerndBreier

timeline.bodyText: This is some kind of precondition checking, isn't it? So we could move it even before "openConnection"?
timeline.author: holgerhagen

replies.bodyText: Ok, just saw that we need the old task impl for some checks. But maybe we could still extract the preconditions (e.g. check that no information is changed that must not be changed)? From my point of view this would improve the maintainability.
replies.author: holgerhagen

replies.bodyText:

The only action I could remove from standardUpdateActions is objectReference.validate().
Should I do this?

timeline.bodyText:
This should rather be placed in TaskServiceImpl, shouldn't it. It has nothing to do with service levels.
Maybe we should rename it to getTasks? It does the same as getTask but or multiple tasks.
timeline.author: holgerhagen

replies.bodyText:
Placing it into TaskServiceImpl creates dependency loops because then TaskServiceImpl depends on ServiceLevelHandler and ServiceLevelHandler depends on TaskServiceImpl.
If we want to move it out of ServiceLevelHandler, we should create a general TaskServiceHelper class that can be called from TaskServiceImpl, ServiceLevelHandler, etc.
In this way we would create a loop-free dependency graph...
replies.author: BerndBreier

timeline.bodyText: These should already be included in the first result, correct? So we should not query the database again.
timeline.author: holgerhagen

replies.bodyText:
This second call retrieves the tasks >after< the update action. The purpose is to identify which tasks were not affected by the update action and to log an error for these tasks.
This cannot be accomplished with the result of the first database call (which happens before the update )
